conclusion: To solve the problem, I will analyze the velocity-time graph to determine the particle's position at \( t = 8 \) seconds. I will calculate the displacement by integrating the velocity over time.

The image shows a velocity-time graph for a particle moving along the x-axis. The graph has three segments: from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 3 \) seconds, the velocity increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s; from \( t = 3 \) to \( t = 5 \) seconds, the velocity remains constant at 2 m/s; and from \( t = 5 \) to \( t = 8 \) seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 to 0 m/s.
The particle starts at \( x = 5 \) meters at \( t = 0 \).

premise: From \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 3 \), the velocity increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s.
conclusion: The displacement in this interval is calculated as \( \Delta x_1 = 9 \text{ meters} \).

premise: From \( t = 3 \) to \( t = 5 \), the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.
conclusion: The displacement in this interval is \( \Delta x_2 = 4 \text{ meters} \).

premise: From \( t = 5 \) to \( t = 8 \), the velocity decreases linearly from 2 to 0 m/s.
conclusion: The displacement in this interval is \( \Delta x_3 = 9 \text{ meters} \).

premise: The total displacement is the sum of these displacements: \( x(8) = 5 + 9 + 4 + 9 \).
conclusion: The position of the particle on the x-axis is 27 meters.
